1 !> \file grrad.f This file is the radiation driver module. It prepares
2 !! the atmospheric profiles and invokes the main radiation calculation.

4 !> \defgroup rad RRTMG Shortwave/Longwave Radiation Scheme
5 !> @{
6 !! \brief The GFS radiation scheme
7 !! \details Radiative processes are among the most complex and
8 !! computationally intensive parts of all model physics. As an
9 !! essential component of modeling the atmosphere, radiation directly
10 !! and indirectly connects all physics processes with model dynamics,
11 !! and it regulates the overall earth-atmosphere energy exchanges and
12 !! transformations.
13 !!
14 !! The radiation package in GFS physics has standardized component
15 !! modules (Table 1). The radiation driver module (\ref
16 !! module_radiation_driver) is the interface with the Interoperable
17 !! Physics Driver (IPD) for NGGPS, and it has three subroutines called
18 !! by IPD (Figure 1):
19 !! - radinit() is called in subroutine nuopc_phys_init to set up
20 !! radiation related fixed parameters.
21 !! - radupdate() is called in subroutine nuopc_rad_update to update
22 !! values between timesteps.
23 !! - grrad() is called in subroutine nuopc_rad_run, and it is the
24 !! driver of radiation calculation.
25 !! \image html ipd_rad.png "Figure 1: Schematic illustration of the communication between the GFS radiation package and IPD " width=10cm
26 !!
27 !! The schematic radiation module structure is shown in Table 1.
28 !! \image html schematic_Rad_mod.png "Table 1: Schematic Radiation Module Structure" width=10cm
29 !!
30 !> GFS radiation package is intended to provide a fast and accurate
31 !! method of determining the total radiative flux at any given
32 !! location. These calculations provide both the total radiative flux
33 !! at the ground surface, which is needed to establish the surface
34 !! energy budget, and the vertical radiative flux divergence, which is
35 !! used to calculate the radiative heating and cooling rates of a given
36 !! atmospheric layer. The magnitude of the terms in the surface energy
37 !! budget can set the stage for moist deep convection and are crucial
38 !! to the formation of low-level clouds. In addition, the vertical
39 !! radiative flux divergence can produce substantial cooling,
40 !! particularly at the tops of clouds, which can have strong dynamical
41 !! effects on cloud evolution.
42 !!
43 !! It uses a correlated-k distribution method and a transmittance lookup
44 !! table that is linearly scaled by optical depth to achieve high
45 !! accuracy and efficiency. The algorithm contains 140 unevenly
46 !! distributed quadrature points (reduced from the original set of 256)
47 !! to integrate the cumulative probability distribution functions of
48 !! absorption over 16 spectral bands. It employs the
49 !! Clough-Kneizys-Davies (CKD_2.4) continuum model (Clough et al. 1992
50 !! \cite clough_et_al_1992) to compute absorption by water vapor at the
51 !! continuum band. Longwave cloud radiative properties external to the
52 !! RRTM depend on cloud liquid/ice water path and the effective radius
53 !! of ice particles and water droplets (Hu and Stamnes 1993 \cite
54 !! hu_and_stamnes_1993; Ebert and Curry 1992 \cite ebert_and_curry_1992).
55 !!
56 !! Changes to Radiation Parameterization since 2007:
57 !! \n The longwave (LW) and the shortwave (SW) radiation
58 !! parameterizations in NCEP's operational GFS are both modified and
59 !! optimized versions of the Rapid Radiative Transfer Model for GCMs
60 !! (RRTMG_LW v2.3 and RRTMG_SW v2.3, respectively) developed at AER
61 !! (Iacono et al. 2008 \cite iacono_et_al_2008,Mlawer et al. 1997
62 !! \cite mlawer_et_al_1997, Iacono et al., 2000 \cite iacono_et_al_2000,
63 !! Clough et al., 2005 \cite clough_et_al_2005). The LW algorithm
64 !! contains 140 unevenly distributed g-points (quadrature points) in 16
65 !! broad spectral bands, while the SW algorithm includes 112 g-points
66 !! in 14 bands. In addition to the major atmospheric absorbing gases of
67 !! ozone, water vapor, and carbon dioxide, the algorithm also includes
68 !! various minor absorbing species such as methane, nitrous oxide,
69 !! oxygen, and in the longwave up to four types of halocarbons (CFCs).
70 !! To represent statistically the unresolved subgrid cloud variability
71 !! when dealing multi layered clouds, a Monte-Carlo Independent Column
72 !! Approximation (McICA) method is used in the RRTMG radiative transfer.
73 !! A maximum-random cloud overlap method is used in both LW and SW
74 !! radiation calculations. Cloud condensate path and effective radius
75 !! for water and ice are used for the calculation of cloud-radiative
76 !! properties. Hu and Stamnes's method (1993) \cite hu_and_stamnes_1993
77 !! is used to treat water clouds in both LW and SW parameterizations.
78 !! For ice clouds. Fu's parameterizations (1996,1998) \cite fu_1996
79 !! \cite fu_et_al_1998 are used in the SW and LW, respectively.
80 !!
81 !! In the operational GFS, a climatological tropospheric aerosol with
82 !! a 5-degree horizontal resolution is used in both LW and SW
83 !! radiations. A generalized spectral mapping formulation was developed
84 !! to compute radiative properties of various aerosol components for
85 !! each of the radiation spectral bands. A separate stratospheric
86 !! volcanic aerosol parameterization was added that is capable of
87 !! handling volcanic events. In SW, a new table of incoming solar
88 !! constants is derived covering time period of 1850-2019 (Vandendool,
89 !! personal communivation). An eleven-year solar cycle approximation
90 !! will be used for time out of the window period in long term climate
91 !! simulations. The SW albedo parameterization uses surface vegetation
92 !! type based seasonal climatology similar to that described in the
93 !! NCEP OFFICE Note 441 (Hou et al. 2002 \cite hou_et_al_2002) but with
94 !! a modification in the treatment of solar zenith angle dependency over
95 !! snow-free land surface (Yang et al. 2008 \cite yang_et_al_2008).
96 !! Similarly, vegetation type based non-black-body surface emissivity
97 !! is used for the LW radiation. Concentrations of atmospheric
98 !! greenhouse gases are either obtained from global network
99 !! measurements, such as carbon dioxide (CO2), or taking the
100 !! climatological constants, the actual CO2 value for the forecast time
101 !! is an estimation based on the most recent five-year observations. In
102 !! the lower atmosphere (<3km) a monthly mean CO2 distribution in 15
103 !! degree horizontal resolution is used, while a global mean monthly
104 !! value is used in the upper atmosphere.
105 !!
106 !> \defgroup module_radiation_driver module_radiation_driver
107 !> @{
108 !! \brief The GFS radiation driver module
109 !! \details module_radiation_driver prepares the atmospheric profile,
110 !! invokes the main radiation calculations, and computes radiative
111 !! fluxes and heating rates for some arbitrary number of vertical
112 !! columns. This module also regulates the logistic running flow of
113 !! the computations, such as data initialization and update accordance
114 !! with forecast timing progress, the sequential order of subroutine
115 !! calls, and sorting results for final output.
116 !! There are three externally accessible subroutines:
117 !! - radinit(): the initialization subroutine of radiation calculations
118 !! It is invoked by the model's initialization process and is independent
119 !! with forecat time progress.
120 !! - radupdate(): calls many update subroutines to check and update
121 !! radiation required but time varying data sets and module variables.
122 !! It is placed inside a model's time advancing loop.
123 !! - grrad(): the driver of radiation calculation subroutines. It sets
124 !! up profile variables for radiation input, including clouds, surface
125 !! albedos, atmospheric aerosols, ozone, etc. It is located inside the
126 !! timing loop, and control the sequence of the radiative process
127 !! calculations.
128 !! \version NCEP-Radiation_driver v5.2 Jan 2013
129 ! ========================================================== !!!!!
130 ! 'module_radiation_driver' descriptions !!!!!
131 ! ========================================================== !!!!!
132 ! !

415 !> This subroutine initialize a model's radiation process through
416 !! calling of specific initialization subprograms that directly
417 !! related to radiation calculations. This subroutine needs to be
418 !! invoked only once at the start stage of a model's run, and the
419 !! call is placed outside of both the time advancement loop and
420 !! horizontal grid loop.
421 !> \param si model vertical sigma interface
422 !> \param nlay number of model vertical layers
423 !> \param me print control flag
424 !> \section gen_radinit General Algorithm

 6 subroutine radinit( si, NLAY, imp_physics, me )
428 !...................................
429
430 ! --- inputs:
431 ! & ( si, NLAY, imp_physics, me )
432 ! --- outputs:
433 ! ( none )
434
435 ! ================= subprogram documentation block ================ !
436 ! !
437 ! subprogram: radinit initialization of radiation calculations !
438 ! !
439 ! usage: call radinit !
440 ! !
441 ! attributes: !
442 ! language: fortran 90 !
443 ! machine: wcoss !
444 ! !
445 ! ==================== definition of variables ==================== !
446 ! !
447 ! input parameters: !
448 ! si : model vertical sigma interface !
449 ! NLAY : number of model vertical layers !
450 ! imp_physics : MP identifier !
451 ! me : print control flag !
452 ! !
453 ! outputs: (none) !
454 ! !
455 ! external module variables: (in module physparam) !
456 ! isolar : solar constant cntrol flag !
457 ! = 0: use the old fixed solar constant in "physcon" !
458 ! =10: use the new fixed solar constant in "physcon" !
459 ! = 1: use noaa ann-mean tsi tbl abs-scale with cycle apprx!
460 ! = 2: use noaa ann-mean tsi tbl tim-scale with cycle apprx!
461 ! = 3: use cmip5 ann-mean tsi tbl tim-scale with cycl apprx!
462 ! = 4: use cmip5 mon-mean tsi tbl tim-scale with cycl apprx!
463 ! iaerflg : 3-digit aerosol flag (abc for volc, lw, sw) !
464 ! a:=0 use background stratospheric aerosol !
465 ! =1 include stratospheric vocanic aeros !
466 ! b:=0 no topospheric aerosol in lw radiation !
467 ! =1 compute tropspheric aero in 1 broad band for lw !
468 ! =2 compute tropspheric aero in multi bands for lw !
469 ! c:=0 no topospheric aerosol in sw radiation !
470 ! =1 include tropspheric aerosols for sw !
471 ! ico2flg : co2 data source control flag !
472 ! =0: use prescribed global mean co2 (old oper) !
473 ! =1: use observed co2 annual mean value only !
474 ! =2: use obs co2 monthly data with 2-d variation !
475 ! ictmflg : =yyyy#, external data ic time/date control flag !
476 ! = -2: same as 0, but superimpose seasonal cycle !
477 ! from climatology data set. !
478 ! = -1: use user provided external data for the !
479 ! forecast time, no extrapolation. !
480 ! = 0: use data at initial cond time, if not !
481 ! available, use latest, no extrapolation. !
482 ! = 1: use data at the forecast time, if not !
483 ! available, use latest and extrapolation. !
484 ! =yyyy0: use yyyy data for the forecast time, !
485 ! no further data extrapolation. !
486 ! =yyyy1: use yyyy data for the fcst. if needed, do !
487 ! extrapolation to match the fcst time. !
488 ! ioznflg : ozone data source control flag !
489 ! =0: use climatological ozone profile !
490 ! =1: use interactive ozone profile !
491 ! ialbflg : albedo scheme control flag !
492 ! =0: climatology, based on surface veg types !
493 ! =1: modis retrieval based surface albedo scheme !
494 ! iemsflg : emissivity scheme cntrl flag (ab 2-digit integer) !
495 ! a:=0 set sfc air/ground t same for lw radiation !
496 ! =1 set sfc air/ground t diff for lw radiation !
497 ! b:=0 use fixed sfc emissivity=1.0 (black-body) !
498 ! =1 use varying climtology sfc emiss (veg based) !
499 ! =2 future development (not yet) !
500 ! icldflg : cloud optical property scheme control flag !
501 ! =0: use diagnostic cloud scheme (discontinued) !
502 ! =1: use prognostic cloud scheme (default) !
503 ! imp_physics : cloud microphysics scheme control flag !
504 ! =99 zhao/carr/sundqvist microphysics scheme !
505 ! =98 zhao/carr/sundqvist microphysics+pdf cloud & cnvc,cnvw!
506 ! =11 GFDL cloud microphysics !
507 ! =8 Thompson microphysics scheme !
508 ! =6 WSM6 microphysics scheme !
509 ! =10 MG microphysics scheme !
510 ! iovrsw : control flag for cloud overlap in sw radiation !
511 ! iovrlw : control flag for cloud overlap in lw radiation !
512 ! =0: random overlapping clouds !
513 ! =1: max/ran overlapping clouds !
514 ! isubcsw : sub-column cloud approx control flag in sw radiation !
515 ! isubclw : sub-column cloud approx control flag in lw radiation !

842 !> This subroutine is the driver of main radiation calculations. It
843 !! sets up column profiles, such as pressure, temperature, moisture,
844 !! gases, clouds, aerosols, etc., as well as surface radiative

846 !! of this subroutine is placed inside both the time advancing loop
847 !! and the horizontal grid loop.

1025 ! DH* gfortran correctly throws an error if the intent() declarations
1026 ! for arguments differ between the actual routine (here) and the dummy
1027 ! interface routine (IPD_func0d_proc in IPD_typedefs.F90):
1028 !

1030 !
1031 ! Since IPD_func0d_proc declares all arguments as intent(inout), we
1032 ! need to do the same here - however, this way we are loosing the
1033 ! valuable information on the actual intent to this routine. *DH

1058 ! ================= subprogram documentation block ================ !
1059 ! !
1060 ! this program is the driver of radiation calculation subroutines. * !
1061 ! It sets up profile variables for radiation input, including * !
1062 ! clouds, surface albedos, atmospheric aerosols, ozone, etc. * !
1063 ! * !
1064 ! usage: call grrad * !
1065 ! * !
1066 ! subprograms called: * !
1067 ! setalb, setemis, setaer, getozn, getgases, * !
1068 ! progcld1, progcld2, progclduni, diagcds, * !
1069 ! swrad, lwrad, fpvs * !
1070 ! * !
1071 ! attributes: * !
1072 ! language: fortran 90 * !
1073 ! machine: ibm-sp, sgi * !
1074 ! * !
1075 ! * !
1076 ! ==================== definition of variables ==================== !
1077 ! !
1078 ! input variables: !
1079 ! type(GFS_control_type), intent(in) :: Model !
1080 ! type(GFS_statein_type), intent(in) :: Statein !
1081 ! type(GFS_sfcprop_type), intent(in) :: Sfcprop !
1082 ! type(GFS_grid_type), intent(in) :: Grid !
1083 ! type(GFS_tbd_type), intent(in) :: Tbd !
1084 ! type(GFS_cldprop_type), intent(in) :: Cldprop !
1085 ! !
1086 ! input/output variables: !
1087 ! type(GFS_coupling_type), intent(inout) :: Coupling !
1088 ! type(GFS_radtend_type), intent(inout) :: Radtend !
1089 ! type(GFS_diag_type), intent(inout) :: Diag !
1090 ! !
1091 ! optional: !
1092 ! real(kind=kind_phys), optional, intent(out) :: htrlw0(:,:) !
1093 ! real(kind=kind_phys), optional, intent(out) :: htrsw0(:,:) !
1094 ! !
1095 ! optional output variables: !
1096 ! htrswb(IX,LM,NBDSW) : spectral band total sky sw heating rate !
1097 ! htrlwb(IX,LM,NBDLW) : spectral band total sky lw heating rate !
1098 ! !
1099 ! !
1100 ! definitions of internal variable arrays: !
1101 ! !
1102 ! 1. fixed gases: (defined in 'module_radiation_gases') !
1103 ! gasvmr(:,:,1) - co2 volume mixing ratio !
1104 ! gasvmr(:,:,2) - n2o volume mixing ratio !
1105 ! gasvmr(:,:,3) - ch4 volume mixing ratio !
1106 ! gasvmr(:,:,4) - o2 volume mixing ratio !
1107 ! gasvmr(:,:,5) - co volume mixing ratio !
1108 ! gasvmr(:,:,6) - cf11 volume mixing ratio !
1109 ! gasvmr(:,:,7) - cf12 volume mixing ratio !
1110 ! gasvmr(:,:,8) - cf22 volume mixing ratio !
1111 ! gasvmr(:,:,9) - ccl4 volume mixing ratio !
1112 ! !
1113 ! 2. cloud profiles: (defined in 'module_radiation_clouds') !
1114 ! clouds(:,:,1) - layer total cloud fraction !
1115 ! clouds(:,:,2) - layer cloud liq water path !
1116 ! clouds(:,:,3) - mean effective radius for liquid cloud !
1117 ! clouds(:,:,4) - layer cloud ice water path !
1118 ! clouds(:,:,5) - mean effective radius for ice cloud !
1119 ! clouds(:,:,6) - layer rain drop water path !
1120 ! clouds(:,:,7) - mean effective radius for rain drop !
1121 ! clouds(:,:,8) - layer snow flake water path !
1122 ! clouds(:,:,9) - mean effective radius for snow flake !
1123 ! !
1124 ! 3. surface albedo: (defined in 'module_radiation_surface') !
1125 ! sfcalb( :,1 ) - near ir direct beam albedo !
1126 ! sfcalb( :,2 ) - near ir diffused albedo !
1127 ! sfcalb( :,3 ) - uv+vis direct beam albedo !
1128 ! sfcalb( :,4 ) - uv+vis diffused albedo !
1129 ! !
1130 ! 4. sw aerosol profiles: (defined in 'module_radiation_aerosols') !
1131 ! faersw(:,:,:,1)- sw aerosols optical depth !
1132 ! faersw(:,:,:,2)- sw aerosols single scattering albedo !
1133 ! faersw(:,:,:,3)- sw aerosols asymmetry parameter !
1134 ! !
1135 ! 5. lw aerosol profiles: (defined in 'module_radiation_aerosols') !
1136 ! faerlw(:,:,:,1)- lw aerosols optical depth !
1137 ! faerlw(:,:,:,2)- lw aerosols single scattering albedo !
1138 ! faerlw(:,:,:,3)- lw aerosols asymmetry parameter !
1139 ! !
1140 ! 6. sw fluxes at toa: (defined in 'module_radsw_main') !
1141 ! (topfsw_type -- derived data type for toa rad fluxes) !
1142 ! topfsw(:)%upfxc - total sky upward flux at toa !
1143 ! topfsw(:)%dnfxc - total sky downward flux at toa !
1144 ! topfsw(:)%upfx0 - clear sky upward flux at toa !
1145 ! !
1146 ! 7. lw fluxes at toa: (defined in 'module_radlw_main') !
1147 ! (topflw_type -- derived data type for toa rad fluxes) !
1148 ! topflw(:)%upfxc - total sky upward flux at toa !
1149 ! topflw(:)%upfx0 - clear sky upward flux at toa !
1150 ! !
1151 ! 8. sw fluxes at sfc: (defined in 'module_radsw_main') !
1152 ! (sfcfsw_type -- derived data type for sfc rad fluxes) !
1153 ! sfcfsw(:)%upfxc - total sky upward flux at sfc !
1154 ! sfcfsw(:)%dnfxc - total sky downward flux at sfc !
1155 ! sfcfsw(:)%upfx0 - clear sky upward flux at sfc !
1156 ! sfcfsw(:)%dnfx0 - clear sky downward flux at sfc !
1157 ! !
1158 ! 9. lw fluxes at sfc: (defined in 'module_radlw_main') !
1159 ! (sfcflw_type -- derived data type for sfc rad fluxes) !
1160 ! sfcflw(:)%upfxc - total sky upward flux at sfc !
1161 ! sfcflw(:)%dnfxc - total sky downward flux at sfc !
1162 ! sfcflw(:)%dnfx0 - clear sky downward flux at sfc !
1163 ! !
1164 !! optional radiation outputs: !
1165 !! 10. sw flux profiles: (defined in 'module_radsw_main') !
1166 !! (profsw_type -- derived data type for rad vertical profiles) !
1167 !! fswprf(:,:)%upfxc - total sky upward flux !
1168 !! fswprf(:,:)%dnfxc - total sky downward flux !
1169 !! fswprf(:,:)%upfx0 - clear sky upward flux !
1170 !! fswprf(:,:)%dnfx0 - clear sky downward flux !
1171 !! !
1172 !! 11. lw flux profiles: (defined in 'module_radlw_main') !
1173 !! (proflw_type -- derived data type for rad vertical profiles) !
1174 !! flwprf(:,:)%upfxc - total sky upward flux !
1175 !! flwprf(:,:)%dnfxc - total sky downward flux !
1176 !! flwprf(:,:)%upfx0 - clear sky upward flux !
1177 !! flwprf(:,:)%dnfx0 - clear sky downward flux !
1178 !! !
1179 !! 12. sw sfc components: (defined in 'module_radsw_main') !
1180 !! (cmpfsw_type -- derived data type for component sfc fluxes) !
1181 !! scmpsw(:)%uvbfc - total sky downward uv-b flux at sfc !
1182 !! scmpsw(:)%uvbf0 - clear sky downward uv-b flux at sfc !
1183 !! scmpsw(:)%nirbm - total sky sfc downward nir direct flux !
1184 !! scmpsw(:)%nirdf - total sky sfc downward nir diffused flux !
1185 !! scmpsw(:)%visbm - total sky sfc downward uv+vis direct flx !
1186 !! scmpsw(:)%visdf - total sky sfc downward uv+vis diff flux !
1187 ! !
1188 ! external module variables: !
1189 ! ivflip : control flag for in/out vertical indexing !
1190 ! =0 index from toa to surface !
1191 ! =1 index from surface to toa !
1192 ! imp_physics : cloud microphysics scheme control flag !
1193 ! =99 zhao/carr/sundqvist microphysics scheme !
1194 ! =98 zhao/carr/sundqvist microphysics +pdf cloud !
1195 ! =11 GFDL cloud microphysics !
1196 ! =8 Thompson cloud microphysics !
1197 ! =6 WSM6 cloud microphysics !
1198 ! =10 MG cloud microphysics !
1199 ! !
1200 ! module variables: !
1201 ! itsfc : =0 use same sfc skin-air/ground temp !
1202 ! =1 use diff sfc skin-air/ground temp (not yet) !
1203 ! !
1204 ! ====================== end of definitions ======================= !
